meanings.definition: (Latin) to draw forth, drag out, prolong, protract
meanings.english_definition: (Latin) to draw forth, drag out, prolong, protract

verb_forms.present_active_indicative: trahō, trahis, trahit, trahimus, trahitis, trahunt
verb_forms.imperfect_active_indicative: trahēbam, trahēbās, trahēbat, trahēbāmus, trahēbātis, trahēbant
verb_forms.future_active_indicative: traham, trahēs, trahet, trahēmus, trahētis, trahent
verb_forms.perfect_active_indicative: trāxī, trāxistī, trāxit, trāximus, trāxistis, trāxērunt
verb_forms.pluperfect_active_indicative: trāxeram, trāxerās, trāxerat, trāxerāmus, trāxerātis, trāxerant
verb_forms.future_perfect_active_indicative: trāxerō, trāxeris, trāxerit, trāxerimus, trāxeritis, trāxerint
verb_forms.present_passive_indicative: trahor, traheris, trahitur, trahimur, trahimini, trahuntur
verb_forms.imperfect_passive_indicative: trahēbar, trahēbāris, trahēbātur, trahēbāmur, trahēbāmini, trahēbantur
verb_forms.future_passive_indicative: trahar, trahēris, trahētur, trahēmur, trahēmini, trahentur
verb_forms.perfect_passive_indicative: tractus sum, tractus es, tractus est, tracti sumus, tracti estis, tracti sunt
verb_forms.pluperfect_passive_indicative: tractus eram, tractus eras, tractus erat, tracti eramus, tracti eratis, tracti erant
verb_forms.future_perfect_passive_indicative: tractus ero, tractus eris, tractus erit, tracti erimus, tracti eritis, tracti erunt

inflection.notes: This is a first conjugation Latin verb.

usage_notes.explanation: *Protrahere* is a Latin verb meaning to draw out, prolong, or protract something, often in a temporal sense (e.g., prolonging life or a period of time). It can also mean to drag something forth or reveal it.

derivatives: protract (English, derived from Latin protractus, the past participle of protrahere)

readability_explanation.text: This entry is for the Latin verb *protrahere*. Understanding requires knowledge of Latin grammar and vocabulary.
